pullRequest.body:
See disccusion on Zulip: https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/weaker.20SuccOrder.2FPredOrder

---

PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

nodes.body:
### PR summary [3bf3615a9e](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/15881/commits/3bf3615a9e39f4c5e705d432770e0f7fe3b9d6bf)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Icc_subset_Ico_succ_right`
`+ Icc_subset_Ico_succ_right_of_not_isMax`
`+ Icc_subset_Ioc_pred_left`
`+ Icc_subset_Ioc_pred_left_of_not_isMin`
`+ Ici_subset_Ioi_pred`
`+ Ici_subset_Ioi_pred_of_not_isMin`
`+ Ico_subset_Ioo_pred_left`
`+ Ico_subset_Ioo_pred_left_of_not_isMin`
`+ Iic_subset_Iio_succ`
`+ Iic_subset_Iio_succ_of_not_isMax`
`+ Ioc_subset_Ioo_succ_right`
`+ Ioc_subset_Ioo_succ_right_of_not_isMax`
`+ lt_succ_of_le`
`+ lt_succ_of_le_of_not_isMax`
`+ pred_coe_of_isMin`
`+ pred_coe_of_not_isMin`
`+ pred_le_pred_of_le`
`+ pred_le_pred_of_not_isMin_of_le`
`+ pred_lt_of_le`
`+ pred_lt_of_not_isMin_of_le`
`+ succ_coe_of_isMax`
`+ succ_coe_of_not_isMax`
`++ _`
`- PredOrder.ofLePredIffOfPredLePred`
`- SuccOrder.ofSuccLeIffOfLeLtSucc`
`- predOrderOfNoMinOrder`
`- pred_coe_bot`
`- pred_coe_of_ne_bot`
`- succOrderOfNoMaxOrder`
`- succ_coe_of_ne_top`
`- succ_coe_top`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

I mentioned this on Zulip too: I think `StrongXOrder` aren't needed. In practice, when we talk about a `SuccOrder` in its current definition, we assume that it's a linear order. There are partial orders satisfying this definition – Yaël gives the example `ℕ ⊕ ℕ`, but these haven't really come up. So instead, we should just have `SuccOrder` without `le_of_lt_succ`, prove it as a theorem in the linear order case, and use those two typeclasses together when needed.

We can generalize the instance 
```
variable [DecidableEq α] [PartialOrder α] [OrderTop α] [SuccOrder α]
instance : SuccOrder (WithTop α) where
```
by removing the `OrderTop` variable (and by making the instance classical and removing `DecidableEq`).
In the definition of `succ` we then use `| Option.some a => ite (IsMax a) ⊤ (some (succ a))`

this also allows us to remove `succOrderOfNoMaxOrder`

> We can generalize the instance
> 
> ```
> variable [DecidableEq α] [PartialOrder α] [OrderTop α] [SuccOrder α]
> instance : SuccOrder (WithTop α) where
> ```
> 
> by removing the `OrderTop` variable (and by making the instance classical and removing `DecidableEq`). In the definition of `succ` we then use `| Option.some a => ite (IsMax a) ⊤ (some (succ a))`
> 
> this also allows us to remove `succOrderOfNoMaxOrder`

Applied. ~~This is slightly weaker than `succOrderOfNoMaxOrder`, as it requires a partial order, but I guess that's ok (I also used `a = succ a` instead of `IsMax` and kept the `DecidableEq` assumption).~~
I need the theorem that a `DecidableEq` `OrderTop` has decidable `IsMax`, as well as a `NoMaxOrder`. What's a good place to put those?

Thanks!

bors merge

Build failed (retrying...):
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10560240993/job/29253293106)

Build failed (retrying...):
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10560421140/job/29253864641)
Canceled.
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10575818573/job/29300292959)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10575818573/job/29300292684)
Feel free to address https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/15881/files#r1728190836 or mark it as resolved
Initial remarks (I haven't checked the Basic.lean file yet).
Other than my above comment, LGTM
Looks good to me, just a few minor questions.
Feel free to address https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/15881/files#r1728190836 or mark it as resolved

Sorry, completely unrelated, but what's this terribly uninformative docstring!

EDIT: Maybe you could take the opportunity to fix it and explain how to mathematically think about `succ`
How do you think of it, mathematically? I mostly think of it as the parent in an inverted tree
I think of it as the unique element that's minimally bigger than `a`, or the first element that's bigger than `a`
I changed the docstring, is it good?

I would prefer the `_of_not_isMax` to always come last in the lemma names, for consistency. Maybe swap the hypotheses around so that it still matches the naming convention
```suggestion
theorem lt_succ_of_le_of_not_isMax (hab : b ≤ a) (ha : ¬IsMax a) : b < succ a :=
```
I applied this, but it makes using it a bit awkward. Is there a way to keep the order while having `of_not_isMax` at the end?

```suggestion
theorem Iic_subset_Iio_succ_of_not_isMax (ha : ¬IsMax a) : Iic a ⊆ Iio (succ a) :=
```

```suggestion
theorem Icc_subset_Ico_succ_right_of_not_isMax (hb : ¬IsMax b) : Icc a b ⊆ Ico a (succ b) := by
```

```suggestion
theorem Ioc_subset_Ioo_succ_right_of_not_isMax (hb : ¬IsMax b) : Ioc a b ⊆ Ioo a (succ b) := by
```

```suggestion
@[gcongr] theorem succ_lt_succ (hab : a < b) : succ a < succ b := by simp
```

This is really supposed to be a one-liner
```suggestion
  ⟨by rintro rfl; exact covBy_succ _, CovBy.succ_eq⟩
```
Is this porting note still relevant?
Yes
Do we generally keep porting notes like these around? I'd imagine once they've been read and discussed they can just be removed. After all, it's not like we're going back to Lean 3.

I tend to agree with Violeta here: This porting note should instead have been a comment in the porting PR, and it's not even keeping any information that we couldn't figure out quickly: Tagging the lemma as simp would give you an error in CI iff the comment is still relevant
Alright, I'll remove it.
It's a bit odd to have these deep nested sections with only a single theorem in each. Can you move the typeclass assumptions into the theorems instead?
Wait, this theorem isn't about `SuccOrder`, is it? It shouldn't be deleted if so.
I thought this is just `le_of_lt_succ` for the following instance, but I now see it doesn't assume LocalllyFiniteOrder. I'll restore it.
Is "minimal" the correct word? Isn't the successor in a partial order always unique, meaning we can replace this by "minimum"?
This definition only assumes a preorder, not a partial order

In a preorder, all minimal elements grater than `a` should be equivalent, I believe? So my statement is still approximately right.

Really, successor orders on preorders are somewhat silly. I don't think we lose anything by defining them for preorders like this, but we should really be thinking about them as either partial or total orders.
Informally, "minimum element" is not something we really say, at least much less than we would say "minimal element", so I'm happy with the docstring as it is

Sorry, "least" element would be the proper wording.

Can we at least still say that it is unique in the case of partial orders?
I changed it to least.

For future reference, this lemma does need a linear order now, else we could consider the partial order `a < ⊤ > b` with `φ` sending `a ↦ b`, `b ↦ a`, `⊤ ↦ ⊤`. It is strictly monotone but `¬ a ≤ φ a`.

Please just remove `[@DecidablePred α IsMax]` and use `classical` or `open scoped Classical in`. 
This predicate will only be rarely provable (e.g. only on finite types with decidable le)
This is actually provable in a partial order with decidable equality, thanks to `succ_eq_iff_isMax`. Should I just use that?
Ah, good point. I'm fine with either option.
maybe add a (simp?)-lemma in a `NoMaxOrder`?
... and this is true in a succ-archimedean order with bot. Same, please write a TODO
This is still true in a non-linear succ-archimedean order. Mind writing a TODO?
Is what I added good?

```suggestion
@[gcongr]
theorem succ_lt_succ (hab : a < b) : succ a < succ b := by
  simp [hab]
```
Don't think that's an improvement?
I thought that was just the Lean 4 style now...
That's how everything was mathported. Doesn't mean it's the style
Fair enough.
Does `simp` not work?
Why doesn't the old definition work anymore?
As [mentioned](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/15881#issuecomment-2296312137) above, using the new definition the instance can be generalized to avoid the `OrderTop` assumption.

In general, we like to glue together series of similar lemmas. It's a visual cue that they are related
```suggestion
theorem succ_lt_succ_iff : succ a < succ b ↔ a < b := by simp

alias ⟨le_of_succ_le_succ, _⟩ := succ_le_succ_iff
alias ⟨lt_of_succ_lt_succ, _⟩ := succ_lt_succ_iff
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - refactor(Order/SuccPred): Remove `le_of_lt_succ` and `le_of_pred_lt` from `SuccOrder`/`PredOrder`

source.title: refactor: split `SuccOrder WithTop` instance into `NoMaxOrder` and `OrderTop`
